titleInfo.title: 17BY11 Rymer, Bradley County, Tennessee. Burials 15BY27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, and 34. Square 16R6. Direction NW

mods.abstract: [15BY27] Juvenile male in fair condition, extended on back with head to NW. Burial lay so close to plow line that pit was not discernible except at level of skeleton. [15BY28] Adult female in good condition, extended on back with head to NW. Left shoulder of 15BY28 adjoins skull of 15BY29--pits converge. [15BY29] Juvenile female in fair condition, extended on back with head to SW. The skull of burial 29 almost touches the left shoulder of burial 28. The evidence is not conclusive that 15BY29 precedes 15BY28, but it is probable owing to the greater depth of 15BY29 and the merging of the two pits. [15BY30] Adult male in poor condition, extended on back with head to NE. [15BY31] Adult female in poor condition, semi-flexed on right side with head to SW. Small, deep pit; position of shoulders and back suggests that body was probably rammed into bottom. [15BY32] Adult male in good condition, extended on back with head to NW. [15BY33] Adult female in fair condition, extended on back with head to SE. Head of the pit for 15BY32 adjoins the foot end of pit for 15BY33. [15BY34] Indeterminate child in poor condition, partly flexed on back with head to SW. Two strips of rotten wood imbedded in soil, one at each end of the pit; at least six strips laid crosswise over burial over entire length. The ends of these strips on the south edge of the pit were about 0.5' above the skeleton--sloping to immediately above the bone on the north edge of the pit. No evidence of offset or similar support in the edge of the pit could be determined; however, the pit narrowed down considerably from top to bottom so that no support would have been necessary.
mods.note: Dendro sample 8 taken from burial 34. See also photograph 19BY11.
